description: From Middle English viage, borrowed from Anglo-Norman viage and Old French voiage, from Latin viaticum. The modern spelling is under the influence of Modern French voyage. Doublet of viaticum.

entries.meaning: A long journey, especially by ship.
(archaic) A written account of a journey or travel.
(obsolete) The act or practice of travelling.

verbs.description: voyage (third-person singular simple present voyages, present participle voyaging, simple past and past participle voyaged)

entries.meaning: (intransitive) To go on a long journey.
examples: A mind forever voyaging through strange seas of thought alone.
